turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, so I have this big interview coming up for a software engineer position at Google, and I'm feeling super overwhelmed. Can you help me prepare?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Absolutely! I can definitely assist you with your interview preparation. To start, could you tell me a bit about the specific role and level you're interviewing for? Knowing this will help me tailor the advice and practice questions.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: It's for a Level 3 Software Engineer position, focusing on backend development. I've been brushing up on algorithms and data structures, but I'm really worried about the system design questions. Honestly, they always throw me for a loop. How do I even begin to approach them?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: System design questions can be tricky! A good starting point is to clarify the requirements. Ask clarifying questions about the scale of the system, the expected number of users, read/write ratio, and any specific performance constraints. Then, focus on high-level components and their interactions. Think about database choices, caching strategies, and load balancing. I can provide some example system design questions relevant to Google's backend systems if you'd like.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, that's helpful. But what if they ask me something completely out of left field, like designing a system for… I don't know… self-folding laundry? I mean, how can you prepare for something *that* random? I get so flustered when I don't know where to start, and I think that's what kills me in interviews.
